transcripts.text: Thank you, thank you, and thank you everyone for being here.  So I was talking to friends about doing this, and they were asking me, why?  Why do you care?  You're not a veteran, and it's true.  I'm not a veteran.  I've never had to do that.  I've never had to take up arms.  And I do want to take this moment to thank every person here, whether standing over here or standing over there, who is a veteran, who has undertaken that risk for the benefit of all of us.  And what I'm here—what I told my friends why I'm here—I'm here for my grandfather, my grandfather, the World War II veteran, who, when he was wading out to a boat rescuing him at Dunkirk or when he was climbing up the rocky slopes of Monte Cassino, he wasn't doing that as a Christian.  He wasn't doing that as part of any religion or part of no religion.  He was doing that as a soldier.  He was doing that fighting for his country and fighting for freedom.  And as you can probably tell, I'm not American.  I'm British, and everyone who is British has a connection to the First World War.  The losses of Britain were staggering in that every war memorial I go to, I can find the name of an ancestor on that war memorial.  And again, when those soldiers, when those sailors were huddled in mud, in trenches, when they were drowning in the.
